g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
including injuries, gastrointestinal problems, infections and respiratory conditions [
]. In addition to
the occupational health risks, poor living conditions, hygiene practices and lifestyle habits increase
their risk of acquiring diseases [
Previous studies have reported associations between working at landÔ¨Åll sites and increased health
risks, such as musculoskeletal disorders of the lower back, shoulders and neck [
]; upper and lower
respiratory symptoms, with a high prevalence of coughs [
]; and mental health disorders [
]. Areview
by Binion and Gutbertlet (2012) reported an increased incidence of respiratory diseases among waste
recyclers exposed to dust, fumes from chemicals and inhalation of sulphurous gases generated by
anaerobic microbial decomposition of organic waste [
]. In addition, a study in Kaohsiung County,
Taiwan, found waste recyclers exposed to chemical residues from household cleaning detergents,
paint and pesticide containers reported acute respiratory symptoms, such as coughing and shortness
of breath, headaches, sinusitis, and nausea [
The health of landÔ¨Åll workers is a
Ô¨Ä
ected by socio-economic factors, such as education status,
living close to landÔ¨Åll sites, informal housing and the use of solid biomass fuels for cooking, such as
wood and coal, which have been shown to increase inhalable particulate materials, thus increasing
the risk of chronic respiratory symptoms [
]. There are few studies investigating health outcomes
associated with waste picking in the informal economy. The scarcity of research on the health of
informal workers in the South African context has necessitated that more research is done on informal
waste recyclers. The objective of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of acute respiratory
symptoms among waste recyclers at two major landÔ¨Åll sites in Johannesburg. The study will further
identify risk factors associated with respiratory symptoms.
2. Materials and Methods
2.1. Study Setting and Population
This study was a cross-sectional study conducted at two landÔ¨Åll sites, situated in the west
and southwest of Johannesburg. There are four Pikitup landÔ¨Åll sites in Johannesburg, Gauteng,
South Africa, where municipal waste is disposed. Two of the largest landÔ¨Åll sites were selected for the
study. LandÔ¨Åll site 1 hosted approximately 3000 waste recyclers and landÔ¨Åll site 2 had approximately
600 waste recyclers. The study population consisted of male and female informal waste recyclers over
18 years of age. Waste recyclers who were available during the study days were invited to participate
in the study. Asurvey sample size calculation provided a sample size of 365, with a conÔ¨Ådence level of
95% and a signiÔ¨Åcance level of 0.05. Using proportional sampling strategy, 82% (
n
299) of waste
recyclers were recruited fromlandÔ¨Åll site 1 and 17%(
n
62) were recruited fromsite 2. Approval was
sought fromthe landÔ¨Åll management, and ethical clearance was obtained fromthe Human Research
Ethics Committee of the University of the Witwatersrand (clearance number M171120) to conduct
the study.
The study was divided into two phases. In phase I, a qualitative health risk assessment of
the two landÔ¨Åll sites was conducted by a trained occupational hygienist, in order to assess safety
practices and to identify hazards associated with the work performed. The risk assessment process
based on the ‚ÄúFive steps to risk assessment,‚Äù developed by the UK Health and Safety Executive
(HSE) [
], was followed. In phase II, waste recyclers were interviewed by trained nurses using a
structured questionnaire.
2.2. Study Variables
2.2.1. Socio-Economic Variables
Data pertaining to the participants‚Äô personal information were collected. These included age,
sex, education, number of years spent working as a waste recycler, and source of fuel used for
cooking, which determined whether they used electricity, para
Ô¨É
n, gas, wood
coal or any other source.
